statement:
Let $G$ be a group and $N\unlhd G$. There is a bijection between $G(N)$,
the set of subgroups of $G$ containing $N$, and the set of subgroups of
$G/N$ defined by $A\rightarrow A/N$. Moreover, for any two subgroups
$A,B$ in $G(N)$, we have

1.  $A\leq B$ if and only if $A/N\leq B/N$,

2.  $A\leq B$ implies $|B:A|=|B/N:A/N|$,

3.  $\ang{A,B}/N=\ang{A/N,B/N}$,

4.  $(A\cap B)/N=(A/N)\cap (B/N)$, and

5.  $A\unlhd G$ if and only if $(A/N)\unlhd (G/N)$.
